comment_data.body:
```suggestion
    it('resets active request after receiving error response from the server', function()
```

comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -369,6 +370,27 @@ test text
     screen:expect({ grid = grid_without_inlay_hints, unchanged = true })
   end)
 
+  it('refreshes hints after been requested', function()
+    exec_lua([[vim.lsp.inlay_hint.enable(true, { bufnr = bufnr })]])
+    screen:expect({ grid = grid_with_inlay_hints })
+    feed('kibefore <Esc>')
+    screen:expect([[
+  before^ {1:01234}test text                             |
+                                                    |*2
+]])

@@ -369,6 +370,27 @@ test text
     screen:expect({ grid = grid_without_inlay_hints, unchanged = true })
   end)
 
+  it('refreshes hints after been requested', function()
+    exec_lua([[vim.lsp.inlay_hint.enable(true, { bufnr = bufnr })]])
+    screen:expect({ grid = grid_with_inlay_hints })
+    feed('kibefore <Esc>')
+    screen:expect([[
+  before^ {1:01234}test text                             |
+                                                    |*2
+]])
+    exec_lua(function()
+      vim.lsp.inlay_hint.on_refresh(
+        nil,
+        nil,
+        { method = 'workspace/inlayHint/refresh', client_id = client_id }
+      )
+    end)
+    screen:expect([[
+  {1:01234}before^ test text                             |
+                                                    |*2
+]])

comment_data.body: `screen:expect()` is good for timing-out instead of hanging. Is it possible to print something, which screen:expect() can assert?

comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -369,6 +370,27 @@ test text
     screen:expect({ grid = grid_without_inlay_hints, unchanged = true })
   end)
 
+  it('refreshes hints after been requested', function()

comment_data.body: There will be an error on the screen, so I added the `screen:expect` here to assert.
so the test won't hang on failure, thus this comment is outdated?
It is still not outdated; although there is `screen:expect`, it will still hang on. However, the error can be seen through `screen:expect`, so I think it is still meaningful
